```Why India.md
India is currently at the center of the largest urban migration in human history, with the United Nations projecting the addition of **416 million urban dwellers by 2050**. While this shift is essential for India’s goal of becoming a $30 trillion economy, current Tier-1 cities are buckling under the pressure. According to a 2022 World Bank assessment, India’s current investment in urban infrastructure averages only **$10.6 billion annually** (roughly 0.6% of GDP), which is less than a quarter of what is required. This has created a massive **$840 billion financing deficit** that must be bridged over the next 15 years to meet basic service demands. The "infrastructure lag" resulting from this gap—manifested in chronic traffic congestion, water stress, and logistics bottlenecks. it is estimated to cost the Indian economy between **2% and 3% of its GDP annually**, effectively acting as a multi-billion dollar "tax" on national productivity.

[Cities as Engines of Growth](https://www.niti.gov.in/sites/default/files/2022-05/Mod_CEOG_Executive_Summary_18052022.pdf)
[2018 World Urbanization Prospects](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XN92srq5jwg)
```

## 1. The Urbanization Pressure Cooker

India is currently at the center of the largest urban migration in human history, with the United Nations projecting the addition of **416 million urban dwellers by 2050**. While this shift is essential for India’s goal of becoming a $30 trillion economy, current Tier-1 cities are buckling under the pressure. According to a 2022 World Bank assessment, India’s current investment in urban infrastructure averages only **$10.6 billion annually** (roughly 0.6% of GDP), which is less than a quarter of what is required. This has created a massive **$840 billion financing deficit** that must be bridged over the next 15 years to meet basic service demands. The "infrastructure lag" resulting from this gap—manifested in chronic traffic congestion, water stress, and logistics bottlenecks—is estimated to cost the Indian economy between **2% and 3% of its GDP annually**, effectively acting as a multi-billion dollar "tax" on national productivity.
[Financing India’s urban infrastructure needs](https://documents1.worldbank.org/curated/en/099615110042225105/pdf/P17130200d91fc0da0ac610a1e3e1a664d4.pdf)
